document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for Mathematics

B916554A0D754CCAB2C7E1898A78FD31.description: communicate methods used, analyses conducted, and conclusions drawn for a data-analysis project through the use of one or more of the following: a written report, a visual display, an oral report, or a multi-media presentation.

A902A2AAA1974A6F8AAC8512B77A0F50.description: formulate a meaningful question, determine the data needed to answer the question, gather the appropriate data, analyze the data, and draw reasonable conclusions; and

B180D704CBBD4E16AB11901C5228842C.description: Mathematical modeling in social sciences. The student applies mathematical processes to design a study and use graphical, numerical, and analytical techniques to communicate the results of the study. The student is expected to:

BB47996013C14E15AD98DA5512FE54E5.description: use regression methods available through technology to model linear and exponential functions, interpret correlations, and make predictions.

D17CB70448AC4006888D82FAC381D9D0.description: analyze marketing claims based on graphs and statistics from electronic and print media and justify the validity of stated or implied conclusions; and

035BF4D2782F404C81533DB1476C365E.description: use data from a sample to estimate population mean or population proportion;

F8E6F1618BAA449CB3CD4CBAC240D3A5.description: distinguish the purposes and differences among types of research, including surveys, experiments, and observational studies;

81B3BB374FCA450AB193659A5D369BC2.description: analyze numerical data using measures of central tendency (mean, median, and mode) and variability (range, interquartile range or IQR, and standard deviation) in order to make inferences with normal distributions;

322AEB87DC664DAC9C62ED9D8A40EF7E.description: interpret information from various graphs, including line graphs, bar graphs, circle graphs, histograms, scatterplots, dot plots, stem-and-leaf plots, and box and whisker plots, to draw conclusions from the data and determine the strengths and weaknesses of conclusions;

45C38F7197AD41FD95CAD30EC49689A1.description: Mathematical modeling in social sciences. The student applies mathematical processes and mathematical models to analyze data as it applies to social sciences. The student is expected to:

E66DFAF9F6FD40BFA0667E73AA6FDEC6.description: use experiments to determine the reasonableness of a theoretical model such as binomial or geometric.

D7F92B0DA37E442A825F0B599205052A.description: compare theoretical to empirical probability; and

2F74AEEF5CFC45F6BF5F645916371C22.description: determine the number of ways an event may occur using combinations, permutations, and the Fundamental Counting Principle;

2F72410375BC4BF4814B6327E7F56482.description: Mathematical modeling in social sciences. The student applies mathematical processes to determine the number of elements in a finite sample space and compute the probability of an event. The student is expected to:

78A5AD18438A4B65897842A3C44F6848.description: use scale factors with two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects to demonstrate proportional and non-proportional changes in surface area and volume as applied to fields.

E1545C00B2694567AA0AF7905D8C4A3F.description: use geometric transformations, proportions, and periodic motion to describe mathematical patterns and structure in music; and

881214D9D50F45789BDD687559C45F63.description: use similarity, geometric transformations, symmetry, and perspective drawings to describe mathematical patterns and structure in art and photography;

A8614A271AFA450FA071A67118CDBE74.description: use trigonometric ratios and functions available through technology to model periodic behavior in art and music;

A36C11986D1F4689B3AABB87F2FD036C.description: Mathematical modeling in fine arts. The student uses mathematical processes with algebra and geometry to study patterns and analyze data as it applies to fine arts. The student is expected to:

306F873840CE43A5B651CDDF2B53267C.description: use trigonometric ratios to calculate distances and angle measures as applied to fields.

7DCFD23595E449428D40F61347648ABF.description: use the Pythagorean Theorem and special right-triangle relationships to calculate distances; and

F6C21798698E4FCE9C996F51A50427EA.description: use scale factors with two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects to demonstrate proportional and non-proportional changes in surface area and volume as applied to fields;

F5DE9504D67841F2A6A7DD1A4AFF7BF3.description: use similarity, geometric transformations, symmetry, and perspective drawings to describe mathematical patterns and structure in architecture;

187D7EEA87DE4580AD92D81A4F379513.description: Mathematical modeling in science and engineering. The student applies mathematical processes with algebra and geometry to study patterns and analyze data as it applies to architecture and engineering. The student is expected to:

99E3B564A5C845AFBDC5094651EB64C1.description: use quadratic functions to model motion.

DA2CD649690A45058538754709D872D3.description: use exponential models available through technology to model growth and decay in areas, including radioactive decay; and

DE8DF694FA6642E9BCA07CEAC329C489.description: use proportionality and inverse variation to describe physical laws such as Hook's Law, Newton's Second Law of Motion, and Boyle's Law;

7B6E57D168D54BEDA9034E076E4EC3B8.description: Mathematical modeling in science and engineering. The student applies mathematical processes with algebraic techniques to study patterns and analyze data as it applies to science. The student is expected to:

78E6228A4BE44B55966EA58057C67536.description: analyze types of savings options involving simple and compound interest and compare relative advantages of these options.

CB88A7D9E705400287B88A68D93CBCB7.description: investigate and compare investment options, including stocks, bonds, annuities, certificates of deposit, and retirement plans; and

8D090ABF36C74F258D89B02946776A13.description: analyze and compare coverage options and rates in insurance;

73AA0D7E266D4BA694856C1C05F2C91B.description: Mathematical modeling in personal finance. The student uses mathematical processes with algebraic formulas, numerical techniques, and graphs to solve problems related to financial planning. The student is expected to:

F021324C48CF43E1B0CB538B25E0A7B3.description: use technology to create amortization models to investigate automobile financing and compare buying a vehicle to leasing a vehicle.

2A06C6C14C704A1CB54D8A8C50D3E446.description: use technology to create amortization models to investigate home financing and compare buying a home to renting a home; and

0454A8BFA6BE4B43B33115E8F1B59639.description: analyze personal credit options in retail purchasing and compare relative advantages and disadvantages of each option;

0EF7543F530C451AB84324CDB4847A28.description: use formulas to generate tables to display series of payments for loan amortizations resulting from financed purchases;

C774D572B912481C86BF749E8A27931F.description: Mathematical modeling in personal finance. The student uses mathematical processes with algebraic formulas, graphs, and amortization modeling to solve problems involving credit. The student is expected to:

CC60570A374F45A9A4353C7F6D363E90.description: analyze data to make decisions about banking, including options for online banking, checking accounts, overdraft protection, processing fees, and debit card/ATM fees.

9EBE9471A9DE4258947F249114D41A4E.description: solve problems involving personal taxes; and

8EB5396735254CAF9B40B6D74C76BDE3.description: use rates and linear functions to solve problems involving personal finance and budgeting, including compensations and deductions;

5D08A677E5D5440FA883F11FE34F927E.description: Mathematical modeling in personal finance. The student uses mathematical processes with graphical and numerical techniques to study patterns and analyze data related to personal finance. The student is expected to:

8E1E267809964778B0B45566BF704B56.description: display, explain, and justify mathematical ideas and arguments using precise mathematical language in written or oral communication.

A1F6C736E1CE472099398465C10894ED.description: analyze mathematical relationships to connect and communicate mathematical ideas; and

385C1407E14F425F99ACDB3E84005329.description: create and use representations to organize, record, and communicate mathematical ideas;

F1B80DA92EB1499CBF989ED7D5215B0A.description: communicate mathematical ideas, reasoning, and their implications using multiple representations, including symbols, diagrams, graphs, and language as appropriate;

A818874C0D1042A891752D4D90353E7E.description: select tools, including real objects, manipulatives, paper and pencil, and technology as appropriate, and techniques, including mental math, estimation, and number sense as appropriate, to solve problems;

2E23C2B6D0904406B751261BE61066AD.description: use a problem-solving model that incorporates analyzing given information, formulating a plan or strategy, determining a solution, justifying the solution, and evaluating the problem-solving process and the reasonableness of the solution;

3A002391021249A6AFCDAEC2649D27C0.description: apply mathematics to problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace;

7E2255F838F14D3CA3E96553D66DDB73.description: Mathematical process standards. The student uses mathematical processes to acquire and demonstrate mathematical understanding. The student is expected to:
